text: what's going on everybody i'm johnny
brooke from crafted workshop back with
another video for the make magazine
youtube channel in today's video i'm
going to show you how to build this diy
home theater projector screen and
building one of these is really simple
and can save a ton of money over a
store-bought option so the other nice
thing is you can kind of customize it to
fit your space add some nice trim and
make it look really really built-in and
custom so very inexpensive very easy to
build you only need a couple tools
really you could do this whole project
with a circular saw and drill and you
end up with a beautiful result so let's
go ahead and get started
so here's the materials you'll need for
this build so first you'll need some one
by fours to use for the frame and the
exact amount of wood you'll need will
depend on the size of your screen next
an optional addition to the frame are
corner braces another optional component
is backband trim and you'll also need
some black paint for the trim if you go
with this next is the screen material i
got my material from carl's place which
is a website that specializes in diy
projector screen material and i'll have
a link in the video description to the
exact item i used last you'll need some
felt tape which i also got from carl's
place
so once i had all my materials on hand i
started cutting my one by fours to size
so my screen ended up at 82 inches wide
which is the maximum that would fit in
my space and for a 16 by 9 ratio which
is the standard for most tv shows and
youtube videos you'll need to divide
your width by 16 and then multiply it by
9 to get your height also make sure to
factor in the felt tape when making
these calculations and this is something
i forgot to do and this caused the final
aspect ratio of my screen to be slightly
off
once i had my pieces cut to length i
drilled pocket holes on both ends of
these short frame pieces and i used
pocket screws to assemble this frame and
they're a simple and strong method of
assembling butt joints a pocket hole jig
can be purchased for as little as
something like 20 bucks and is a really
handy tool to have on hand
so to assemble the frame i clamped the
pieces together making sure they were
nice and flush and then added inch and a
quarter pocket screws and there are
three short pieces on my frame one on
each end and one in the center for extra
support
after assembling the frame i added
corner brackets to the four outside
corners of the frame
and again these aren't strictly
necessary but they really help to add
rigidity since the last thing you want
is your frame flexing and causing
wrinkles on your screen
next i started cutting the backband trim
to size and i started by cutting a 45
degree miter on one end of the trim and
then clamped it onto the frame and
marked where i needed to cut i then went
back to the miter saw and made the cut
leaving it a little long on the first
cut and when cutting trim it's really
best to sneak up on the fit by making
multiple cuts like this i just continued
doing this working my way around the
frame until i had all the trim fit
once the pieces were cut to length i
applied a few coats of black spray paint
and this trim came already primed so
that saved me quite a bit of work when
painting
to mount the frame to the wall i used a
french cleat and this is a really simple
mounting bracket and can be cut from a
piece of scrap wood so to create the
fringe cleat i ripped a piece of scrap
wood down the center at a 45 degree
angle and i used my table saw but you
could do this with a circular saw and
straight edge if you don't have a table
saw
next i mounted one half of the cleat to
the back of the frame using a few inch
and a quarter screws and you can see how
the cleat forms a hook which will grab
onto the matching piece that will be
mounted to the wall
when using a french cleat you also need
to add a spacer to the bottom edge of
whatever you're mounting so that it's
spaced evenly from the wall all the way
around
to mount the cleat to the wall i used a
few four inch screws making sure to
drive them into a stud and also making
sure the cleat was level
so next it was time for the most
nerve-wracking part of this build and
that was installing the screen material
so the key here is to really just take
your time and follow the pattern
outlined on the carl's place website you
basically want to attach the screen
using a stapler moving in a star pattern
going from the center of the frame out
towards the edges
just take your time and make sure any
wrinkles are removed along the way i
unfortunately rushed this a little bit
and ended up with a few wrinkles but
nothing major and nothing you can really
notice with the projector on
after attaching the screen i trimmed
away any excess with a utility knife and
i purposely got one size larger than i
needed so that i could trim the screen
to fit
next i installed the felt tape
i cut a 45 degree miter on each corner
using a speed square and applied the
tape making sure not to pull too hard on
the tape as this will create wrinkles
i just worked my way around the frame
taking my time and making sure i didn't
go over the edge of the frame and the
trim will cover any overhanging screen
material around the edges
after installing the felt tape i
installed the trim using a brad nailer
an inch and a quarter brad nails
finally i installed the screen using the
french cleat and it fit perfectly one
other nice thing about the french cleat
system is that i can easily remove the
screen if i need to access the area
behind the screen at any time
the last thing i needed to do was
install my projector a benq hd 3050 and
i thought since i have a drop ceiling
and this is a bit of a unique install
i'd show this since i had to get a
little creative with the mounting
i just created a bracket using some
scraps that mounted to the floor joists
above the drop ceiling
so to install the projector i just used
the two bolts that were included with
the mount and i'll have a link to the
exact mount i used in the video
description
and after installing the mount i secured
the projector into place
adjusted the position and then fired it
up
with that the projector screen project
was done
all right hopefully you guys enjoyed
this one this project was really simple
but i am super happy with the final
result and this is a massive upgrade for
me i was running a 42-inch plasma screen
prior to this so
this is pretty amazing i feel like i'm
really at the movies and you could go a
lot bigger with this the the projector
i'm using which is the bin q ht3050 it's
a fairly budget friendly projector it'll
go up to 180 inches diagonally so if you
have the wall space you could build this
thing as big as you want using the same
techniques so hopefully you guys enjoyed
this one if you don't already check out
my youtube channel i have tons more
woodworking projects over there i put
out new project videos every week i'll
have a button for you to click to go
over there and thanks again to the guys
at make magazine for having me on their
channel alright guys until next time
happy building
[Music]
you
